gov.usgs.volcanoes.core.data

Class Wave

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.usgs.volcanoes.core.data.Wave
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    BinaryDataSet, Cloneable, Comparable<Wave>

    public class Wave
extends Object
implements BinaryDataSet, Comparable<Wave>, Cloneable
    AWave is a class that handles regularly sampled time-series data like a seismic waveform. This class is well suited to higher sampling rate data (>10Hz) with little or no gaps.

    All data are stored as 32-bit signed integers. The start time, as in the whole USGS Java codebase, is in j2ksec (decimal seconds since Jan 1, 2000).

    Author:
    Dan Cervelli

      • Wave

        public Wave(ByteBuffer bb)
        Constructs a Wave from an array of bytes. This constructor is best used when transmitting Waves over a network.

        The order of the binary variables is as follows: startTime, samplingRate, registrationOffset, number of samples (integer), and then the buffer of samples.

        Parameters:
        bb - the byte buffer.

      • register

        public void register()
        Registers the starting time to the nearest even interval based on the wave's sampling rate. The offset between the original start time and the registered time is stored in registrationOffset.

      • fft

        public double[][] fft()
        Computes the FFT of the Wave. This function will perform the necessary zero-padding in order to make the samples buffer be a power of 2 in size.
        Returns:
        the FFT (n rows x 2 column [real/imaginary]) array
        See Also:
        FFT

      • getEndTime

        public double getEndTime()
        Gets the end time for this wave. This is equals to the samples * period, so it reports the time AFTER the last sample, not FOR the last sample.

        TODO: Tom says this is silly. Make endTime the end time by subtracting 1 from samples(). Look carefully for side effects.

        Returns:
        the end time

      • getRegistrationOffset

        public double getRegistrationOffset()
        Gets the registration offset of this wave.
        Returns:
        the registration offset

      • getDataRange

        public int[] getDataRange()
        Gets the minimum and maximum values of this wave. This is safe to use in a loop -- a new int array is not generated on each call.
        Returns:
        an array with minimum and maximum value (in that order)

      • adjacent

        public boolean adjacent(Wave wave)
        Determines whether or not this wave is adjacent to another wave in time. Allows a samplingRate/4 fudge factor to account for rounding errors.
        Parameters:
        wave - the test wave
        Returns:
        whether or not these waves are adjacent

      • overlaps

        public boolean overlaps(Wave wave)
        Determines whether or not this wave overlaps the other wave in time. This does not cover cases where they are adjacent to each other, use adjacent() for that.
        Parameters:
        wave - the test wave
        Returns:
        whether or not these waves overlap

      • overlaps

        public boolean overlaps(double t1,
               double t2)
        Determines whether or not this wave overlaps a given time interval. This does not cover cases where they are adjacent to each other, use adjacent() for that.
        Parameters:
        t1 - the start time of the interval
        t2 - the end time of the interval
        Returns:
        whether or not these waves overlap

      • split

        public Wave[] split()
        Splits this wave in half, creating two separate waves.
        Returns:
        an array of two waves

      • split

        public List<Wave> split(int maxSamples)
        Splits this wave into a list of smaller waves with a maximum number of samples as specified. Used for breaking a wave into TRACEBUF-sized pieces.
        Parameters:
        maxSamples - maximum number of samples
        Returns:
        a list of the split up waves.

      • subset

        public Wave subset(double t1,
          double t2)
        Gets a strict subset of this wave. This function should have more bounds checking. It will fail if you ask for a portion of wave that is not contained in the original wave.
        Parameters:
        t1 - the start time of the subset
        t2 - the end time of the subset
        Returns:
        the subset wave

      • erase

        public void erase(double t1,
         double t2)
        Expiremental. For use with Winston static importers. TODO: handle erase a chunk inside the existing wave
        Parameters:
        t1 - start time
        t2 - end time

      • combine

        public Wave combine(Wave wave)
        Combines this wave with another overlapping one. This function will return a combination of the two waves. This may modify this wave before returning it. Neither wave is guaranteed to be safe from modification.

        This is only intended to work on overlapping waves (as checked by the overlap() function.

        Parameters:
        wave - wave object
        Returns:
        combined wave

      • join

        public static Wave join(List<Wave> waves)
        Joins together a list of waves into one large wave. The list must be sorted in time-ascending order of start time. Technically, as long as the first wave is the earliest and the last wave ends the latest, this function will work. This function will happily create a wave with large gaps in it as well.
        Parameters:
        waves - the list of Wave s
        Returns:
        the new joined wave

      • join

        public static Wave join(List<Wave> waves,
        double t1,
        double t2)
        Joins together a list of waves into one large wave. Forces extent of wave from arguments so sort order does not matter.
        Parameters:
        waves - the list of Wave s
        t1 - start time
        t2 - end time
        Returns:
        the new joined wave

      • getMemorySize

        public int getMemorySize()
        Gets an estimate for the size in RAM of this Wave. It doesn't count the size of the header information, assuming instead that it is insignificant compared to the size of the buffer.
        Returns:
        the approximate size in RAM of this wave in bytes

      • integrate

        public double[] integrate()
        Integrates the wave. This functions takes the cumulative sum (mean removed) of the wave at each sample, dividing by the sampling rate.
        Returns:
        an array of the sum at each sample

      • removeMean

        public double[] removeMean()
        Debiases the wave. This functions subtracts the mean from every sample.
        Returns:
        an array of the sum at each sample

      • filter

        public void filter(Butterworth bw,
          boolean zeroPhaseShift)
        Filter data.
        Parameters:
        bw - Butterworth filter to apply
        zeroPhaseShift - flag for no phase shift

      • toBinary

        public ByteBuffer toBinary()
        Creates a ByteBuffer that wholly contains this Wave. This is used before sending a Wave over a network (or potentially into a file). The ByteBuffer needs to be flipped before it can fed somewhere.
        Specified by:
        toBinary in interface BinaryDataSet
        Returns:
        the bytes that make up the wave

        Specified by:

        Parameters:
        bb - ByteBuffer
